instruction: What metric was chosen to assess the hydraulic properties of the soil and how far can this metric go in estimating Ks and FWC?
Output:
The metric chosen to assess the hydraulic properties of the soil in this study was the crop water stress index (CWSI). This index was used as an indicator of crop water stress, which was then used to estimate the saturated soil hydraulic conductivity (Ks) and field water capacity (FWC). 

The study found that the approach using CWSI was able to estimate Ks with good results, with a coefficient of determination (R2) value of 0.77 for stands with developed crop water stress. 

For the estimation of FWC, the results varied depending on the depth of the soil layer. For the topsoil layer (0-0.3 m), the R2 values ranged from 0.38 to 0.99.
